description: Atrial fibrillation is an arrhythmia where the atria of the heart cannot beat normally, leading to an irregular heartbeat. Atrial rates can reach 350–600 beats per minute, making the atria unable to contract effectively. It is commonly referred to as atrial fibrillation or AFib.
symptoms: Shortness of breath during physical activity, night sweats
diagnosis: Electrocardiogram (ECG): the most commonly used tool to diagnose atrial fibrillation
24-hour Holter monitor: detects intermittent atrial fibrillation
Echocardiogram: observes heart structure and function
Blood tests: rule out other conditions such as hyperthyroidism

general: Regularly monitor heart rhythm and blood pressure; watch for palpitations or fatigue
Treat associated chronic conditions such as hypertension and diabetes
diet: Avoid diets high in cholesterol, salt, and fat
Increase intake of vegetables, fruits, and whole grains
Maintain a healthy weight and avoid obesity
exercise: Engage in moderate and regular exercise, such as brisk walking and stretching
Consult a doctor before starting an exercise routine
monitoring: Attend regular follow-up appointments and ECG checkups
Be aware of medication side effects
lifestyle: Maintain a regular schedule and get enough sleep
Manage stress and avoid emotional extremes
Quit smoking and avoid excessive drinking
Prevent colds and be mindful of seasonal changes

risk_factors: Valvular heart disease and other heart conditions
complications: Thromboembolism (in organs other than the brain)
domestic: Atrial fibrillation is the most common arrhythmia
Prevalence exceeds 5% in those over 65, and 10% in those over 80
Atrial fibrillation is linked to stroke; about 1 in 6 strokes is related to AFib
ethnic: Prevalence is higher among Whites compared to Blacks and Asians
Risk factors such as hypertension vary across ethnic groups
Genetic background influences the risk and presentation of atrial fibrillation
Clinical presentation and treatment response may differ slightly by ethnicity
